dspace-development.title: Document the integration and deployment of the Symplectic Elements rt4ds service for the OAR

comments.body: A significant section of this should address the collection mapping when "depositing" Publications from within Elements (which, in turn, uploads a file as a Bitstream for a newly-created Item within the OAR). Currently the RT4DS extension for DSpace 5.5 is used in order to support the synchronization operations, and one **must** ensure that the user within Elements has a valid `Primary group descriptor` which references an OAR DSpace Collection **by name**.

pulfalight.title: Implement collection-level badges indicating the access permissions for the resource

comments.body: I'm going to move this to blocked until we know exactly what to do here. We can add more information to the EAD if necessary, but some examples I looked at in `asqa` don't seem to have the collection marked as restricted even if there's an access restriction note.

@Trey This is a migration issue that we're hoping Lyrasis will address in the next iteration. They didn't act on our `@type="closed"/"review"`, so the notes imported, but the restrictions weren't set. This should be fixed next time (not the new ingest we're waiting for now, the one after that).

@hackartisan In a resource record, the note of  "type"=>"accessrestrict" basically has three meaningful pieces: 
* the boolean "restricted", which would indicate that a restriction exists
* "rights_restriction", which indicates the type of restriction (we'll use "Restricted" and "Review" from the time of import, which are both "local_access_restriction_type"=>[])
* the "content"=>"", which is the narrative note.

For the badge, I think you'd want to map to the rights_restriction field. FYI "Restricted" means it's closed; "Review" means someone needs to check whether or not it's closed; the wording of the badges is a question for Public Services.

pulfalight.title: we need a way to get structured access restrictions out of ASpace
Automated accessibility testing
we need a way to get structured access restrictions out of ASpace

comments.body: Closed as duplicate of #429

This allows specific start and end dates to be attached to an access restriction. My understanding is it's functionality ADAPT wants to make use of going forward (we're not importing data with this structure).

Here is an example I cooked up from a resource record. We'd want to display the "begin" and "end" dates of the restriction. @Will-Clements or @faithc can probably provide more detail.

"rights_restriction"=>{"begin"=>"2019-12-01",
"end"=>"2021-09-23",
"local_access_restriction_type"=>["Restricted"]},
"subnotes"=>[{"jsonmodel_type"=>"note_text",
"content"=>"This is generically restricted",
"publish"=>false}],
"publish"=>false}],
"uri"=>"/repositories/5/resources/635",
"repository"=>{"ref"=>"/repositories/5"}
(Sorry, I started responding to this duplicate by mistake, so have reopened this and closed the other)

pulfalight.title: Add "Suggest a Correction"

comments.body: @hackartisan I did try it with the flash in the main page, the problem is to get to suggest a correction you're probably scrolled down, so you click the thing, it closes out, and you can't see the flash message which has appeared but above the cut. I could scroll them up but it seems unnecessarily disruptive.
Hm, that's interesting. And the button is all the way at the bottom of the page?

@hackartisan It's below the descriptive metadata.

![Screen Shot 2020-11-10 at 1 42 56 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2806645/98737207-bd9ace00-235a-11eb-8825-1f5e722914c5.png)
What about clearing the modal and just having the flash message then? I think it is sort of confusing to present the form again.
@hackartisan I left the form so they wouldn't have to refresh the page again to submit another request, and I don't have to dynamically load the form on clicking the button.
Do people want to submit more than one correction by filling out the form multiple times? That would be surprising to me.

@hackartisan I'm not sure, but they probably don't want to close out of the modal and get thanked again if they hit that button until they refresh. I can make it load the form dynamically on clicking the button if this is a blocker, I personally think the way it works now is pretty nice.

Okay. I don't really like it but it seems like it's up to the POs and I won't block on it.

Unfortunately I wasn't able to give this pr more than a very quick look. It seems good but I wouldn't want to approve without a closer review. if someone else reviews it feel free to override my block to merge.

btw, thank you for all the screenshots!
Don't merge this please, I think the location codes being used are wrong but I'm done for the night.
